column1: 4.2.4.3.3.4	Recommendations for complicated stress urinary incontinence

Management of complicated stress urinary incontinence (SUI) should only be offered in 
centres with appropriate experience (see Section: 4.2.4.3.1).

Base the choice of surgery for recurrent SUI on careful evaluation, including individual 
patient factors and considering further investigations such as cystoscopy, multichannel 
urodynamics, as appropriate.

Inform women with recurrent SUI that the outcome of a surgical procedure, when used as 
second-line treatment, is generally inferior to its use as first-line treatment, both in terms of 
reduced efficacy and increased risk of complications.

Only offer adjustable mid-urethral sling as primary surgical treatment for SUI as part of a 
structured research programme.

Consider secondary synthetic sling, bulking agents, Burch colposuspension, autologous 
sling or artificial urinary sphincter (AUS) as options for women with complicated SUI.

Inform women receiving AUS or ACTÂ® device that, although cure is possible, even in expert 
centres, there is a high risk of complications, mechanical failure, or a need for explantation.
